results.title: Stories from the earth
results.creator_credit: Katie Jennings and KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Fire on the rim”.
In days long gone, the lack of factual explanation for the eruptions, quakes and ancilliary disasters throughout the “ring of fire”, gave rise to myths and legends as means of coping with the impact of the erratic disturbances. Cultures both old and new have been partly shaped by such events, producing beliefs affecting the social behaviour of people living with the unpredictability of the earth. This program examines some of the fascinating stories that have emerged in these communitites.

results.title: Prediction problem
results.creator_credit: Katie Jennings and KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Fire on the rim”.
Careful planning with technological innovation can minimise the damage and death caused by seismic activity. The education of peoples in lands around the “ring of fire” also assists in avoiding unnecessary disaster. Although scientists can make intelligent guesses about the movement of the earth, the predicition of earthquakes and eruptions remains an imperfect art. The study of historical evidence coupled with intensive research around the Pacific Rim, is helping to gain a clearer picture of the problem.

results.title: Researching the topic
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Finding out”.
Demonstrates the principles of student research through the experiences of a secondary student who is required to do a research project on any aspect of “people and work”. As the practicalities of the task are confronted the audience is guided through the key stages of project planning, information collection and processing, formulating conclusions and presentation. Accompanied by 13p Teacher Notes.

results.title: Preparing and conducting an interview
results.creator_credit: Justin Shortal and Video Education Australasia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Finding out”.
Kylie’s class has been set the task of recording an interview with an aspect of their own choice. We follow Kylie’s progress as she moves through a process of preparing and conducting an interview.

results.title: The Best Remaining Seats
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
John Baxter, well known Australian historian and cinema critic, examines the fall of the great cinema houses, how the Hollywood industry built them and Hollywood acted as a magnet for both talent and money. Charlie Chaplin’s career is also analysed. This episode is one of the “Filmstruck” series which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: Filmstruck Series
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Going It Alone
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Filmmaking has never really been studio based. John Baxter, well known Australian film historian and cinema critic, interviews some of the independents. He also takes a look at the Disney animation studio in Burbank, as well as showing us rare footage of a surrealist “Snow White” starring Betty Boop. this program is the final episode in the “Filmstruck” series which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: Switzerland/Texas
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Filming in Australia has been described as “Switzerland wanting to go to Texas”. In this program, John Baxter, well-known Australian film historian and cinema critic, looks at the state of the Australian film industry. This is part five of a ten part documentary “Filmstruck” which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.
